title: Graphs for block sliding down an incline

content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is released from rest at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> at the top of an inclined plane. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the surface is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Î¼</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following sets of graphs best represents the speed of the block and the height above the ground of the block as functions of time?

choices.label: The figure presents two graphs in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane. The first graph has a horizontal axis labeled Time, in seconds, and the vertical axis labeled Speed, in centimeters per second. The line begins approximately three quarters of the way up the vertical axis above the origin and moves downward and to the right at a constant rate, ending at the rightmost point on the horizontal axis aligned with the origin. The second graph has a horizontal axis labeled Time, in seconds, and the vertical axis is labeled Height, in centimeters. The line begins approximately three quarters of the way up the vertical axis above the origin and moves downward and to the right at a constant rate, ending at the rightmost point on the horizontal axis aligned with the origin.

The figure presents two graphs in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane. The first graph has the horizontal axis labeled Time, in seconds, and the vertical axis labeled Speed, in centimeters per second. The line begins approximately three quarters of the way up the vertical axis above the origin and moves downward and to the right at a constant rate, ending at the rightmost point on the horizontal axis aligned with the origin. The second graph has a horizontal axis labeled Time, in seconds, and the vertical axis labeled Height, in centimeters. The line begins approximately three quarters of the way up the vertical axis above the origin and curves downward and to the right at an increasing rate, ending at the rightmost point on the horizontal axis aligned with the origin.

The figure presents two graphs in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane. The first graph has the horizontal axis is labeled Time, in seconds, and the vertical axis labeled Speed, in centimeters per second. The line begins at the origin and moves diagonally upward and to the right at a constant rate, ending at the rightmost point on the horizontal axis and at the top of the vertical axis. The second graph has the horizontal axis labeled Time, in seconds, and vertical axis labeled Height, in centimeters. The line begins at the origin and curves upward and to the right at an increasing rate, ending at the rightmost point on the horizontal axis and at the top of the vertical axis.
